author: Brad Crouch
title: Cruise deals you should book this week
text:
IT’S the bill on cruise ships that more and more people are grumbling about — the internet tab. While some people regard the only true holiday as one away from contact with the outside world, in an age of email, social media and 24/7 news many people want to be connected when they feel like it.
While most cruise lines offer packages it comes at a hefty cost, and connection time is so slow a package of, say, 100 minutes slips by very quickly. Some lines offer it for free — while lazing your way around the Fiji islands on Captain Cook Cruises’ Reef Endeavour you can post your photos on social media for free and check your emails.
Luxury line Silversea has announced it will provide free Wi-Fi on all its ships from next January. Guests will be provided a minimum of one hour free Wi-Fi, rising to unlimited access depending on suite category. The free service fits with Silversea’s all-inclusive policy on its all-suite ships, which covers drinks and gratuities.
It is a challenge for other cruise lines in an era when people expect to be able to hook up to the world through their smartphones and tablets, even while lounging by the pool — and social media shots of people having a good time is surely good advertising for cruise lines.
EYES ON ASIA
ROYAL Caribbean Cruises is answering the demand for cruises through Asia with more ships and itineraries across its three brands — Royal Caribbean International, Celebrity Cruises and Azamara Club Cruises offering 24 voyages to 34 ports this season.
Royal Caribbean Cruises Australasia commercial director Sean Treacy said the popularity of the brands’ cruises in Asia had quadruped in five years.
“This incredible demand has been met by an increase in capacity and the number of ships that now service the region — starting from one in 2007 and now with six beautifully modern ships regularly based in Asia,” he said.
“We’re also seeing a strong trend for family group cruises and multi-generational cruises. We often find that many families with ties to the region choose a cruise to reconnect with loved ones.” Popular cruise destinations include Bangkok and Phuket in Thailand, Kuala Lumpur and Penang in Malaysia, Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam and Bali in Indonesia.
 Izumi Japanese Restaurant in Voyager of the Seas cruise ship. Picture: Royal Caribbean Cruises Source: Supplied
TRIPPING TO TASSIE
COMBINE a cruise on one of the world’s largest ships with a tour of Tasmania. The eight-night deal departing on November 28, 2015 and priced from $2169 per person twin-share starts with a flight from Adelaide, Brisbane or Melbourne to Sydney for a four night cruise on Voyager of the Seas from Sydney to Hobart with a day call in Melbourne.
With 10 pools and whirlpools, 14 bars and lounges, multiple dining options and facilities from an ice-skating rink to a surf simulator Voyager is a destination in itself. The package includes four nights in Hobart’s Hotel Grand Chancellor with breakfast, a half-day city tour, a full-day tour of historic Port Arthur, a half day Cadbury factory tour with Derwent River cruise, and a full day Museum of Old and New Art with Mt Wellington tour. Flights back to Adelaide, Brisbane or Melbourne are included.
Ph 1300 854 897 or see www.holidaysofaustralia.com.au
FAST TRACK TO NZ
CREATIVE Cruising and AAT Kings have partnered on a fly, cruise and coach package from Christchurch to Sydney, but move quickly to grab it. The packages include flight to Christchurch, a six night AAT Kings’ Great Glacier Explorer coach tour visiting Mt. Cook, Queenstown, Franz Josef Glacier and a TranzAlpine Rail Journey back to Christchurch, flight to Auckland, two-night pre-cruise accommodation at Scenic Hotel Auckland, and 14-night premium cruise to Sydney on-board Holland America Line’s ms Noordam. The 22-night package is priced from $5549 and includes a USD$75 on-board credit per stateroom. Offer is valid until July, 7, 2015 and departs from Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane on October 31, 2015.
Ph 1300 362 599 or see creativecruising.com.au
 Cruise ship Pride of America. Source: Supplied
THREE SHIPS AHOY
COMPARE three ships on a 43-night epic holiday combining four cruises from Alaska to the tropics. The trip starts with a flight from Sydney to Vancouver with a night to relax before joining Holland America Line’s Noordam on a seven-night cruise through Alaska’s famous Inside Passage calling at Juneau, Skagway and Ketchikan.
After four nights in a hotel in Vancouver join HAL’S Volendam for a seven night cruise from Vancouver to Honolulu via Seattle as the snow landscapes turn to surf and sun. After three nights in a hotel in Waikiki, a seven-night exploration of the Hawaiian Islands follows aboard Norwegian Cruise Line’s Pride of America . Then rekindle memories back aboard Noordam for a 14 night cruise to Sydney calling at Samoa, Fiji and New Caledonia. The package costs from $9899 per person twin-share, valid until the end of July, departing on September 11, 2015.
See worldwidecruisecentres.com.au
SAIL THE WORLD
VISIT 45 destinations on a voyage of 120 nights around the world on a ship named in honour of Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan who led the first circumnavigation of the world. The voyage aboard the 1250-passenger ship departs Tilbury, England, on January 5, 2017, calling at Amsterdam then heading for the Azores in the Atlantic and the Caribbean before transiting the Panama Canal on course to the Mexican Riviera, Tahiti, the Cook Islands and New Zealand, before visiting Sydney, the Whitsundays, Townsville, Cairns and Darwin.
From Australia, the itinerary takes in ports across Asia, the Maldives, India and Oman as well as Egypt, the Suez Canal and the Mediterranean, ending the four-month odyssey back in Tilbury on May 5, 2017. Sectors include 27 nights from Sydney on February 23, 2017, to Hong Kong from $3899 per person, twin-share, or the full 120-night world voyage from $17,550 per person, twin share.
Ph 1300 764 509 or see cruiseexpress.com.au
IT’S CHILE OUTSIDE
SAIL on the Queen Mary 2 from Santiago to Sydney over 25 nights priced from $5399 per person twin-share. Fly from Australia to Santiago on February 14, 2016, and spend three nights at the W Santiago including a city tour and private transfers. Board the luxury QM2 in Valparaiso and set sail for Australia with port visits, including Easter Island, Papeete and Moorea in Tahiti and Auckland, Bay of Islands and Wellington in New Zealand before arriving at Sydney. This package is also available over 27 nights with the final cruise destination being Brisbane, priced from $5759 per person twin-share.
Ph 1300 369 848 or see ecruising.travel
